text: politics in Iraq can be a matter of life
and death
but this Baghdad election rally last
week
first one explosion and then watch the
white van on the right
33 were killed here by Sunni militants
targeting the she act crowd a grisly
start to elections in a country already
soaked in sectarian violence west of
Baghdad under armed escort we headed to
the border with Anbar province this is
the road to Fallujah the city has fallen
to al-qaeda inspired militants Isis just
an hour from the capital Iraqi
government control ends this is as far
as we can go we're told that Anbar isn't
safe the fighting there means that large
parts of the province won't be able to
vote that will further marginalize
Iraq's Sunni community politics here
over the past few years has been about
exploiting sectarian divisions and the
fear is that this election could make
matters even worse Iraq's army is being
outmatched by the insurgents so in an
exodus largely unseen nearly half a
million have fled their homes a few are
willing to talk for fear of reprisals
but these weren't wanted the story told
their homes have become a battleground
Fallujah Ramadi have been cursed by God
Allah high since the day we were born
we've had no peace the government need
to help us what sin did woman old men
and children commit
was a crowded field of candidates Prime
Minister Nuri al-maliki is hoping for a
third term Shiite he blames foreign
Sunni influence for the rise in violence
his main rival former prime minister
Ayad Allawi says the world has forgotten
Iraq the shameful thing is not only
what's happening in Iraq the shameful
thing is that this is happening under
the very eyes and ears of the
international community and we see a
country which is systematically being
destroyed Sunni militia the staff are
fighting alongside the Americans helped
turn the tide against Al Qaeda during
the war sheikh abu salim kept fighting
recently seizing an isis weapons cache
and putting it out of action but the
militants soon took their revenge at
lindlar he told me he killed my wife
headed my son the americans abandoned us
but it's the government i blame
they've given us no support how can i go
on without my family as the polls close
this evening iraq stands as a rare thing
a democracy in the middle east but it's
a country in crisis this vote may not be
enough to deliver it from the brink
quentin Somerville BBC News Baghdad
